title: 114_s2170
content: The "Veterans E-Health and Telemedicine Support Act of 2015" or the "VETS Act of 2015" allows Department of Veterans Affairs health care professionals to provide treatment via telemedicine. The "VETS Act of 2015" allows covered health care professionals to practice telemedicine across state lines, regardless of location, for treatment under Chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code. The "VETS Act of 2015" allows covered health care professionals to practice telemedicine across state lines for treatment under Chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code, in a facility owned by the Federal Government. This section does not affect obligations under the Controlled Substances Act and defines a covered health care professional as authorized by the Secretary and licensed in a State to practice the health care profession. The "VETS Act of 2015" allows covered health care professionals to practice telemedicine across state lines for treatment under Chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code. Telemedicine is defined as using technology to provide health care when the patient and health care professional are geographically separated. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will submit a report on the effectiveness of telemedicine used by the Department of Veterans Affairs, including assessing veterans' and healthcare providers' satisfaction with telemedicine services. The report will evaluate the impact of telemedicine provided by the Department of Veterans Affairs on veterans' access to healthcare, frequency of telemedicine use, healthcare providers' productivity, appointment wait times, and the potential decrease in veterans' use of services at Department and non-Department facilities. The report will assess the impact of telemedicine by the Department of Veterans Affairs on veterans' healthcare access, frequency of use, providers' productivity, appointment wait times, and potential cost savings, including travel expenses.
